root.pub-comments: Node not named by author. "This paper deals with the relationship between the Jaminjungan languages (referred to hereafter as Yirram) around the Lower Victoria River, Northern Territory, and languages in a geographically seperate area to the east commonly called the Barkly languages since their territories occupy the western side of the Barkly Tablelands in East Central Northern Territory. Following a 1980 paper to the Australian Linguistic Society and a detailed research report of 83 pages to the Northern Territory University in early 1984 by the author, a number of Australianist linguists have accepted that there is a non-continguous genetic relationship between the languages in these two areas. In between the areas lies the territory of the Ngumbin languages which are effectively unrelated to the Yirram or Barkly languages" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
root.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB)" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB)" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB)" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB)" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB)" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "I call the languages to the east of Jingulu the Eastern Group (E.GROUP). In this group there are four communalects, socially regarded as separate languages. Linguistically, however, Wambaya (WA), Kundanja (KU), and Binbinka (BIN) form a dialect continuum, and since the territories of all three touch on the McArthur River I call this continuum the McArthur Subgroup (MC.SB). To the immediate north-east of Jingulu, Ngarnka (NGN) is closely related to MC.SB, although a separate language" (Chadwick 1997: 95-96).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Adjacent and to the east of the Ngumbin Group lies the territory of Jingulu (JI), one of the Barkly languages" (Chadwick 1997: 95). "The genetic relationship of the Eastern Group to Jingulu is somewhat obscure" (Chadwick 1997: 96).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Yirram group occupy areas around the lower Victoria River in the Northern Territory near the border with Western Australia" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Yirram group occupy areas around the lower Victoria River in the Northern Territory near the border with Western Australia. Of these, Jaminjung (JA) and Ngaliwurru (NGAL) are close enough to be regarded as dialects of the same language, although the two peoples are socially quite separate. These two are labelled the BAJ Subgroup (BAJ.SB) from the word for language found in both" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Yirram group occupy areas around the lower Victoria River in the Northern Territory near the border with Western Australia. Of these, Jaminjung (JA) and Ngaliwurru (NGAL) are close enough to be regarded as dialects of the same language, although the two peoples are socially quite separate. These two are labelled the BAJ Subgroup (BAJ.SB) from the word for language found in both" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Yirram group occupy areas around the lower Victoria River in the Northern Territory near the border with Western Australia. Of these, Jaminjung (JA) and Ngaliwurru (NGAL) are close enough to be regarded as dialects of the same language, although the two peoples are socially quite separate. These two are labelled the BAJ Subgroup (BAJ.SB) from the word for language found in both" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "In an adjacent area to the east lies the territory of Nungali (NU) which is very closely related to the BAJ.SB [Baj Subgroup]" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
